Award.AwardTitle: Annual Phenomenology Symposia will held May 5-7, 2014 at the University of Pittsburgh in Pittsburgh, PA.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PHENO conference series provides a unique forum for experimentalists and theoretical physics to come together and discuss the latest developments in high-energy particle physics and cosmology. The topics discussed include emerging physics made possible by recent experiments at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the European Laboratory for Particle Physics in Geneva, Switzerland. Particle physicists will discuss connections between LHC experimental results and results from other collider- and non-collider based experiments in elementary particle physics. As such, PHENO will emphasize a variety of current topics in particle physics phenomenology, collider physics, neutrino physics, particle astrophysics, and cosmology, as well as new theoretical and computational developments. The 2014, 2015 and 2016 PHENO conferences will be held each May at the University of Pittsburgh.

NSF support for this conference is critical for early-career physicists, students and postdocs, to attend the PHENO Symposia. For many graduate students in particle physics, PHENO represents the first forum where they showcase their research. Students and postdocs have the opportunity to meet their peers, gain valuable research feedback, and develop contacts with senior physicists. A series of parallel sessions provides the participants with the opportunity to give brief accounts of their current research and start new collaborations. To encourage young participants to attend, the tradition of the PHENO conferences is that graduate students can attend the PHENO Conferences free of charge, and postdocs have a reduced conference fee compared to more senior participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pheno 2016 was a great success. It was held May 9-11, 2016 at the University of Pittsburgh. The participants came from a very large swath of current fields of interest and were well represented by experts in both theory and experiment. The project summary report was submitted earlier. Some highlights are:

  • Total participants: 259

  • Woman participants: 32

  • Faculty/scientist participants: 72

  • Postdoc participants: 63

  • Student participants:124

  • States represented by participants: 24

  • Participants from under-represented states: 6

  • Countries represented by participants: 16

    The plenary talks were selected from a broad range of theoretical and experimental topics of current importance. They were split between 11 theorist talks and 7 experimentalist talks. The complete plenary schedule can be seen on page 4. Some highlights of our 18 plenary talks were:

  • ATLAS, CMS, and LHCb experiments

  • Higgs theory and measurements

  • New developments in perturbative QCD

  • Cosmology and dark matter theory and experiments

  • Flavor theory and experiments (Belle-II etc.)

  • Neutrino theory and experiments

  • Physics at the ILC

  • Perspectives on the future of HEP

Requests for parallel talks were submitted by participants in advance and arranged into 24 sessions covering two afternoons. There were a total of 177 talks this year covering more technical details of the participants research. Of these 177 talks, approximately 45 were by experimentalists. Priority for the slots in these sessions was given first to students and then to postdocs. A summary of the parallel sessions can be seen on page 5 while the complete parallel sessions can be seen on pages 6-9. The sessions were organized into the following categories:

  • Dark Matter (3 sessions)

  • Supersymmetry (3 sessions)

  • BSM physics (5 sessions)

  • BSM Higgs physics (2 sessions)

  • Diphoton resonances (2 sessions)

  • Cosmology and Astroparticle physics

  • Higgs physics

  • Neutrino physics

  • Heavy Flavors

  • QCD and Electroweak physics

  • Top quark physics

  • Extra Dimensions

  • Future Colliders

  • Tools and Quantum Field Theory

    As in years past, graduate students and postdocs made up a significant part of our participants this year. One of the trademarks of the Pheno Symposium is the large participation by students. It boasts the largest number of student presentations about their research in any high energy physics meeting in the US. In fact, many students give their first-ever conference talk at our Pheno symposium. A breakdown of the percentages of students and postdocs of the participants and parallel session talks follows:

  • Student percentage of participants: 52%

  • Postdoc percentage of participants: 22%

  • Student percentage of parallel session talks: 61%

  • Postdoc percentage of parallel sessions talks: 30%

    In addition to giving students and postdocs priority for giving parallel session talks, Pheno has a long tradition of minimizing the costs for students and postdocs. In fact, the registration fee is waived completely for students and reduced significantly for postdocs.
